         <div class="fs12 news_span">
          <div class="mw30 mw_m50 mr15 mb5 fl">
           <img alt="New drug could protect against nuclear radiation exposure" class="mw100 mb5 brd" id="ctl00_mediamainlistContainer_p_mainImg" src="/News/7987/230x185/Gabor-Tigyi, radiation exposure.jpg"/>
           <div class="clear">
           </div>
           <span class="c88 fs12 fs_m10 wbw" id="ctl00_mediamainlistContainer_lbl_imgDesc">
            Gabor Tigyi, Professor, University of Tennessee Health Science Center. (C) Elsevier
           </span>
          </div>
          <!--INFOLINKS_ON-->
          <p id="ctl00_mediamainlistContainer_p_news">
          </p>
          <p class="MsoNoSpacing">
           <span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">
            TENNESSEE, US: The 2011 Fukushima disaster was a stark reminder of the continuing dangers posed by nuclear fallout, highlighting the need for an approved drug that can be taken after radiation exposure to protect against organ injury and death.
           </span>
          </p>
          <p class="MsoNoSpacing">
           <span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">
            A study published by Cell Press in Chemistry &amp; Biology identifies a drug candidate called DBIBB that increases the survival of mice suffering from radiation syndrome, even when treatment started three days after radiation exposure. The findings suggest that DBIBB shows promise for becoming the first drug capable of treating acute radiation syndrome caused by the high levels of radiation released by nuclear explosions.
           </span>
          </p>
          <p class="MsoNoSpacing">
           <span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">
            The 21st Century has presented humankind with unforeseen challenges, including the possibility of radiation terrorism. We hope that the scientific community and our efforts will provide protection through medical countermeasures against the harmful effects of ionizing radiation and also help humans to benefit from the useful effects of nuclear technology, said Gabor Tigyi, Professor, University of Tennessee Health Science Center (UTHSC).
           </span>
          </p>
          <p class="MsoNoSpacing">
           <span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">
            Nuclear explosions can expose humans to high levels of ionizing radiation, which can cause cell death and organ injury due to DNA damage. Although some agents tested by the military can provide some protection against radiation sickness when taken prior to radiation exposure, no approved drug is effective when taken after radiation exposure.
           </span>
          </p>
          <p class="MsoNoSpacing">
           <span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">
            In previous studies, Tigyi and his collaborators found that a molecule called lysophosphatidic acid (LPA), which is naturally generated during the course of blood clotting, activates the LPA2 receptor to protect against radiation-induced cell death. The researchers also previously identified an LPA-like compound that protected mice from radiation-induced death, but it did not specifically target the LPA2 receptor or possess the desired drug-like potency required for clinical use.
           </span>
          </p>
          <p class="MsoNoSpacing">
           <span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">
            To overcome this hurdle, Tigyi and his team developed a computational model of the LPA2 binding site and refined their previously identified compound into a more potent and specific activator of the LPA2 receptor, which is abundantly expressed in the most radiation-sensitive types of cells in mammalian tissues. The resulting compound, called DBIBB, protected mouse embryonic skin cells from radiation-induced DNA damage and enhanced the survival of radiation-exposed blood cells, intestinal cells, and other types of cells from mice and humans. Moreover, 93 per cent of mice that were treated with DBIBB three days after radiation exposure remained alive 30 days later, compared with only 20 per cent of mice that were not treated with the drug candidate.
           </span>
          </p>
          <p class="MsoNoSpacing">
           <span style="font-size: 12.0pt;">
            This promising compound will soon join the regulatory pipeline of a biotech company called RxBio Inc., which was cofounded by Tigyi and other UTHSC faculty. Humankind might soon have a defense against unintended radiation exposure. This technology can potentially also help cancer patients from the side effects of radiation therapy and astronauts from chronic exposure to cosmic rays on their journey to Mars, said Tigyi.
           </span>
          </p>
          <p>

        <script type="text/javascript">
         $(function () {
                      var limit = 2000;
                      var tb = $('textarea[id$=txt_comment]');
                      $(tb).keyup(function () {
                          var len = $(this).val().length;
                          if (len &gt; limit) {
                              //this.value = this.value.substring(0, 50);
                              $(this).addClass('exceeded');
                              $('#error').text(len - limit + " characters exceeded");
                          }
                          else {
                              $(this).removeClass('exceeded');
                              $('#error').text((limit - len) + " characters left");
                          }
                      });

                      $('input[id$=btn_subComment]').click(function (e) {
                       
                          var len = $(tb).val().length;
                          if (len &gt; limit) {
                              e.preventDefault();
                          }
                      });
                  });
//                  function clickShare() {
//                      document.getElementById("shareBoxDiv").style.display = "block";
//                 }
//                 function clickClose() {
//                     document.getElementById("shareBoxDiv").style.display = "none";
//                 }
        </script>
